This is an interesting question
So, this is a question about auto
So remember auto is that keyword you use if you don't want your type
And you want C++ to kind of figure out what type the right hand side expression is
So somebody asked the question
What if I have int m and int n and then auto x = n / m
So I'm dividing two integers
Does C++ know to make that auto variable be a double?
No, unfortunately not
In general if you divide two integers you're always going to get back an integer
So if you wanted to make sure you are getting a double, you would have to explicitly cast one of the integer arguments into a double
Or assign it into a temporary double and then use that as part of the calculation
So that's a good question, because that may be not obvious what happens when you're dividing two integers
That should true even if you said double k = n / m where n and m are integers
It's going to give you an integer value and then assign that integer value into a double
It's not actually going to give you a floating point value
In the video it said after you compile object files using -c
So you have clang++ std = whatever
Stdlib = whatever
-c name of file
We output object files
And then you said we need to fill in the blanks
When does the filling in the blanks happen? That's the linking step
Okay, so the compiling with -c makes your object files the object files are sort of incomplete
They are machine-level instructions but they are missing some parts
The linking step is what links everything together and sort of fills in
I actually know where that lives now, it's over at this part of the binary
And I know where that lives, it's over there
And so it ties everything back together so that you actually have a full, complete program
The linking step is that
So, you may have a compiler error when making an object file, or you may have a compiler error when you're linking
So there's compiler errors when you're making the actual machine code for functions or for a class when we make it to classes
Or linking errors when it can't fill in the gaps
So maybe you declared a function and then never defined it
So then it would be a linking error because you promised that there would be this function  with this signature somewhere
And then failed to tell me where, so that would be a linking error
So even within compilation there's kind of two steps
There's generating the code and there's linking
